posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

>>14613460
Hitler wasn't completely unjustified in disagreeing with his generals. He was completely correct when attesting that they commonly ignored the economic realities of war, hence the focus of the likes of Halder on capturing Moscow rather than the resource-rich southern territories. He was also correct in prioritizing the Kiev pocket over allowing Guderian to continue driving towards Moscow. Leaving a massive concentration of Soviet troops behind the front was a recipe for disaster. Finally, it was Hitler's stand-fast orders that allowed the German Army to withstand the Moscow counteroffensive. Had he listened to his generals who wanted to retreat, something akin to a rout may have come about due to the lack of any real defensive lines to retreat to while valuable equipment would have to be abandoned.

He wasn't completely right in all things but the "madman Hitler" myth that Halder and others perpetuated was but an convenient excuse that allowed them to pass the blame for their own mistakes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14605117
>Or Westeros' historiography is in a truly abysmal state and most of that world's known history is a complete fabrication
Compare this to Scandinavia history.
Because the Norse didn't write anything down before Christian conversation, we don't know anything about pre-Christian kings of Denmark, Sweden, and Norway. Only sources come from sagas that contradict each other and were written down only after three centuries after the conversion.
Take Harald Fairhair for instance, his historicity has been brought into question, because there is no solid evidence he ever existed, and many historians think he is a proto-type to justify the reign of the first Christian king of Denmark, Harald Bluetooth.
Then you have insane people like 12/13th century Saxo Grammaticus who fabricated the entire Danish line of kings predating the birth of Jesus (see Gasta Danorum).

Is it really a stretch to assume that some North had Saxo Grammaticus of their own who fabricated a bullshit line of kings for the Starks and it was accepted as factual?

They heavily influenced many Germanic peoples, but many Huns were already mixed by the time they entered the Germanic orbit. Specifically they had a huge component of Scythians sarmatians and proto Slavs. Germanic peoples such as the gepids, goths, rugi, heruli, and others were known for their skill with cavalry. In fact the romans called these people Scythian rather than German because Germans weren’t known to ride their horses into battle, rather dismount and form an infantry line before charging. These cavalry tactics were originally from eastern Iranian peoples but became reinforced by hunnic overlordship as for them the horse and horse based warfare was the most important thing in life. Even some “western” Germanic peoples like the longobards and Thuringians were introduced to these concepts, probably during the hunnic phase, as they became great cavalry peoples. Specifically we know the Longobards had either mixed hunnic kings, or kings in complete subjection to the Huns and their culture penetrated to the entire longobard society. The kings Lethuc, aldihoc, and godehoc have what Capo calls “Turkic ceremonial names” with the translations representing possibly Germanic or hunnic prefixes with the Turkic suffix -juks being represented in Latin as -hoc/huc. This dynasty, which was intrusive to longobard society as it was not descended from the original kings, was responsible for the greatest part of their migration from north east of the Elbe down into Pannonia, most likely influenced by their nomadic overlords and new taste for horsemanship.

Wearing revealing clothing isn’t asserting your freedom.
I’m a feminist who is against crop-tops and revealing clothing (and I’m writing this as someone who loves crop tops). Far from being some kind of cranky old woman with antiquated values, I think women wearing just a bit more clothing is a big part of the solution to sexism.
The reason I think this is simple.
When women wear less clothing, we are giving misogynists exactly what they want.
It serves misogynists for feminists to think that being scantily clad is an expression of freedom. It gives misogynists exactly what they want—consequence-free access to female bodies. They go to their other male friends and spread it, and on the cycle continues.
If getting naked were really the answer to gender relation problems, men would be doing it too. But we are not seeing a sudden popularity spike in the male crop-top, nor are we seeing any other kind of male-revealing clothing become popular.
Every year, women are wearing less and less clothing while men continue wearing the same amount of clothes as ever.
And look, I get it. When I go out, I feel the same pressure to be the sexiest bitch at the bar that every other woman does. My eyes rake over the most attractive women in public, measuring myself against them. (They didn’t start doing this until I started competing for male attention).
But we have to ask ourselves: Where does this lead? Women walking around in bikinis and fishnet while men are still wearing their suits?

>>14615960
The British 'excessive love' of tea was mostly a medical thing. During the Industrial revolution huge numbers of people moved from rural agricultural communities and work into the cities to take jobs in the factories. As horrific as the living and working circumstances were by modern standards it was still a huge step up for them, as you were paid a fixed wage in return for relatively light labour (by the standards of pre-mechanisation agriculture) rather than getting a share of the farms profits every harvest.

That huge influx of people into British industrial cities and towns broke the sewage systems to the point where they ended up with contaminated drinking water, leading to cholera outbreaks. There was a huge response to that once that had started that lead to some really interesting developments (such as the sanitary movement, and the first time that 'Germ Theory' was applied outside of academic papers). One of the best responses they had to control and reduce the spread of cholera though was to make sure that people were boiling their drinking water with a leaf that releases a natural antiseptic solution when placed in boiling water (tea leaves, in case that wasn't clear).

The only place to acquire tea leaves on the scale needed was the Chinese Empire, who refused the proposed free trade deal and insisted on forcing all foreign merchants to trade with an imperial monopoly (the Hong) who set prices well above market rates. China absolutely had the right as a sovereign nation to do that, but shouldn't have been at all surprised that the sovereign state they were screwing over like that had to start looking for other ways to ensure that tens of thousands of their citizens didn't die from preventable disease.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14614130
>In the Middle Ages did the peasants consider their feudal masters to be a different race from themselve
Not if they both belonged to the same people. Yes if you mean something like Greek peasants after the Ottoman conquest of Greece.
>The average nobleman had a much better diet
Citation needed. More tasty? Surely, but the idea that they had a considerably more nutritious diet is questionable. Peasants ate a varied diet of grains, vegetables, nuts and meats.
>Is there evidence that the peasants were intimidated by the aristocracy
No, at least not all the time. Flemish peasants certainly weren't intimidated by French nobility, see the battle of the golden spurs.
>and considered their lordship to be just
The rule of some nobles was considered just, and that of others was considered unjust. Depends on context.
>and their subordinate position in the hierarchy a natural consequence of their inferiority?
No. It wouldn't be framed like that, as a matter of "inferiority" and "superiority". The medieval conception of the three estates is about cooperation. The peasant is not inferior to the noble, they are just different, the peasant toils the land while the noble fights. Both have obligations and duties towards the other. It would be very unchristian to say that a given human is "naturally superior" to other humans, if anything they could be better due to their moral character, but that's unrelated to their position in society.

The Soviets supported the Germans on the premise that a war between Germany and the Maritime Powers would result in both being weakened allowing for the expansion of Soviet power. The conditions the Soviet gave for formally joining a Four Power pact with Italy, Japan, and Germany were unacceptable to Germany given it would create an even greater Soviet stranglehold over the essential resources Germany was extracting from Scandinavia and Romania in addition to those resources that the Soviets were directly supplying them and could withhold at at a whim - something they did at one point only to reverse their position following the shocking German victory over the Allies in Norway and Denmark. Granted, it's likely that neither were acting in good faith when Ribbentrop made his offer and Molotov later replied with Stalin's conditions.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14614540
>Do you think Stalin should have accepted the offer? Did Hitler ever offer to give the Soviets more power in China?

Not to my knowledge on the China question as that was supposed to be Japan's sphere of influence.

Both Germany and Japan - with the latter also courting the Soviets - seemed to be pushing the Soviets to engage in a conflict with Britain by making references to the Indian Ocean being Stalin's sphere of influence. While Japan seemed to be genuine in wanting to bring the Soviets on side given the bulk of their ambitions pertained to British, Dutch, and American colonial possessions in the Pacific, I'm under the impression that Hitler always had his eyes on the east and might have even used a Soviet attack on Britain as a way of coming to terms with the Western Powers so as to form that Anti-Communist Bloc he dreamt of in the past.

So, I certainly don't think Stalin should have unilaterally accepted the offer. Conceding Finland, Romania, and Bulgaria to Germany would have been an act of good but at the cost of imperative Soviet strategic interests.

The Tao is part pleroma and part "God is your wonderful human imagination" (---Neville Goddard), i.e. The Law of Assumption. Taoism is one of the many forms of gnosticism, and one of the ones prior to Neville Goddard which knew about the power of human consciousness to shape the world around one. That is why if you read the Tao Te Ching, it sounds like a handbook for instituting slavery and slave morality in both subject and master.

When in fact, it's about creating the conditions for conscious manifesting in a way that will always be beneficial to the practitioner. Wu wei is the same thing as Neville teaching that manifestation requires no action.
The cosmology in the Tao Te Ching is apparently roughly equivalent to that propounded by Occidental gnostics, with the "nameless" evidently being pleroma and the "named" being the demiurge/demiourgos. The "straw dogs" bit seems to refer to both the indifferent manipulation of the manifestor and the malevolence of the demiurge and archons.

If I could remember more details about the Chuang Tzu, which I read around 10 years ago and haven't revisited since, I could throw that in here.

You practice Taoism by meditating/ to achieve gnosis so that you can return to pleroma when you die, and so that you can manifest a better life for yourself and others as you live until then. You have to learn to recognize your spiritual oneness with "the universe" and universal consciousness, and you will live accordingly.

>The first time Nixon and Kennedy debated was not in 1960, in fact it was on April 1, 1947 when the two new Congressmen debated in McKeesport, Pennsylvania before an audience of 150. The two were invited there to speak by 18th District Congressman John Kunkel and debate on Taft-Hartley. The debate lasted three hours and Nixon remembered it as very friendly and cordial. He thought he got the better of it because the audience at the debate was mostly local business owners (ie. Republicans) rather than blue collar workers. Nixon and Kennedy then took a train back to Washington DC, where the two were bunkmates in a sleeping car, the former on the bottom berth and the latter the top.

>Although the two were never intimates, they were on quite amicable terms with each other until the bitter animosity of the '60 presidential campaign. Kennedy sent Nixon two books as presents, a few friendly notes, and Nixon was invited to Kennedy's wedding with Jacqueline Bouvier in 1953. When Nixon set off for his Congressional fact-finding trip to Europe in August 1947, Kennedy thought he might enjoy some nookie on the trip. He gave Nixon the phone numbers of three suitable young ladies in Paris, including his own sister Patricia. According to Nixon's secretary Rosemary Woods, "Dick was so mortified at this suggestion that I think he just took the paper with the phone numbers written on it and threw it away."

>>14614272
Unless you have some meme diagnosis like dysthymia which arguably isnt depression at all, clinical depression or major depressive disorder is not a permanent state of mind. It is by it's DSM-V definition, defined by it's episodic nature, usually lasting between 6-15 months if untreated before going into remission.

If you're dealing with chronic feelings of depression, then you're looking at either a personality disorder or a side effect of an reaction to a disorder like ADHD.

So if you've been "depressed for 10 years", you're probably not looking at major depressive disorder, but other issues like shit life syndrome or personality disorders.

>>14614321
Well, as a continuous entirely non-syncretic tradition, it kind of is. Until the early-mid 20th century, quasi-pagan folk practices were common across all of rural Europe. The Sami too had their own shamanic religion up until modern times which included elements of Norse paganism like the god Horgalles, their version of Thor.

Still, its not exactly difficult to reconstruct the most fundamental aspects. Say you want to worship the Norse gods, what do you do? A historically attested practice is to build a Hörgr, a small cairn of stones, and to pour offerings of water, beer or sacrificial blood over it. The more esoteric practices may be mostly lost to us, but we can have a reasonable idea of what some of them entailed. Seiðr was probably a shamanic practice which may have involved spinning (as in spinning yarn, not like a dervish) in a trance-like state as a means to effect magical change. Galdr involved performing magical chants. Carving bindrunes involves combing runes into a monogram where the letter-meaning, the symbology and numeric value of the runes used creates a magical formula. There are also modern rituals created by neopagans like the Hammer Rite and runic divination. While they're not historical, if you believe in the existence of the Norse gods, there's no reason why new rites and practices can't be created to commune with them,

>>14614014
>>14614030
There are a lot of Yeshu mentioned in the Talmud which makes it hard to distinguish. You're probably referring to Yeshu the Sorcerer and Yeshu the Heretic. Both these individuals were unlikely to be Jesus because they lived about a hundred years apart from him. Yeshu the Sorcerer was executed by the Hasmoneans while Yeshu the Heretic was a contemporary of Rabbi Akiva who lived in the early 2nd century. The claim of Jesus boiling in excrement comes from a story in which a spirit from Gehenna is summoned by Onkelos, the nephew of Emperor Titus asking the spirits if he should convert to Judaism. The spirit is never referred to by name except a footnote which names it Yeshu, but this might have been post hoc. I should note the Talmud is not a source of authority in Judaism but a commentary written by various Rabbis of different backgrounds and opinions over thousands of years so it should not be a surprise that some have very negative views on Christians.

>James Buchanan, the only Pennsylvanian to be elected president, had been a Federalist in his youth as a lawyer in Lancaster. He was elected to Congress in 1820 and during the party realignments of the next several years ended up as a Jacksonian Democrat. >He had been in office barely six months when the Panic of 1857 engulfed the nation--the boom that followed the California Gold Rush had brought widespread prosperity to the country, and even Virginia, which had been in a decades-long depression, bloomed in the rosy economic conditions. This changed in the fall of 1857 as Northeastern cities were lined with desperate unemployed men. Hundreds wrote pathetic letters to the Naval Yard in NYC hoping for a government job, usually without success. The South was not as directly affected by the depression and some Southerners came to believe it proved the correctness of their system. The worst of the panic was over in a year but the US economy remained sluggish until the second half of 1861 when a flood of war orders brought about a renewed boomtime in the North.
